info.name: Grocery Shop API
info.description: ## API Documentation ### Overview The **API** allows clients to manage products in a grocery catalog (create, read, update, etc.). This documentation focuses on the **Update product** endpoint within this API. ### Base URL and Environment Setup All requests use the `{{baseUrl}}` variable so you can easily switch between environments (local, staging, production). 1. Go to **Environments** in Postman and either create a new environment or edit an existing one. 2. Add a variable: - **Key**: `baseUrl` - **Initial value**: e.g. `http://localhost:8080` (or your actual API host) - **Current value**: same as initial, or another environment‑specific value. 3. Select this environment in the **environment dropdown** in the top right of Postman. All requests in the [Grocery Shop API](https://collection/5083062-5e6f8226-f7dc-405a-90fc-33c01b2a4e4e) collection will now resolve `{{baseUrl}}` using this value. ### Authentication (Bearer Token) The API uses **Bearer token** authentication. 1. Obtain an API token from your auth/identity service. 2. In Postman, set an environment or collection variable: - **Key**: `api_key` - **Value**: your token value 3. In the request **Authorization** tab, choose **Bearer Token** and set: - **Token**: `{{api_key}}` Example HTTP header sent by Postman: ``` http Authorization: Bearer {{api_key}} ``` You can also set this at the **collection level** so all requests in [Grocery Shop API](https://collection/5083062-5e6f8226-f7dc-405a-90fc-33c01b2a4e4e) inherit it. --- ## Endpoint: Update product - **Request name in collection**: [Update product](https://request/5083062-581dd298-29aa-4c7b-911e-cf41ed2ea539) - **Method**: `PUT` - **URL**: `{{baseUrl}}/api/v1/products/:code` ### Description Updates an existing product with the provided details. ### Path variables - `code` (string, required): Unique product code identifying the product to be updated. Example: `CF`. In the open request, this is configured as a **Path variable** with key `code` and current value `CF`. ### Request headers - `Content-Type: application/json` - `Accept: \\\\*/\\\\*` - `Authorization: Bearer {{api_key}}` (if auth is enabled as described above) ### Request body Body type: **raw** JSON. Schema (based on the current request body): ``` json { "basePrice": 3, "code": "string", "name": "string" } ``` Field descriptions: - `basePrice` (number, required): Base price of the product. Example: `3`. - `code` (string, required): Product code. Should usually match the path `code`. Example: `"CF"`. - `name` (string, required): Human‑readable product name. Example: `"Coffee"`. ### Example request ``` http PUT {{baseUrl}}/api/v1/products/CF Authorization: Bearer {{api_key}} Content-Type: application/json Accept: */* { "basePrice": 3, "code": "CF", "name": "Coffee" } ``` ### Example responses This request has saved examples that you can view under the **Examples** section of the [Update product](https://request/5083062-581dd298-29aa-4c7b-911e-cf41ed2ea539) request. #### 200 OK – Product updated successfully Saved example: **"Product updated successfully"** Example body (from the active 200 response): ``` json { "code": "CF", "name": "string", "basePrice": 3 } ``` #### 400 Bad Request – Invalid input Saved example: **"Invalid input"** This response is used when the provided input data is invalid (for example, missing required fields or invalid format). Check the example in the **Examples** tab of the [Update product](https://request/5083062-581dd298-29aa-4c7b-911e-cf41ed2ea539) request for the exact payload. ### How to call this endpoint from Postman 1. Open the [Grocery Shop API](https://collection/5083062-5e6f8226-f7dc-405a-90fc-33c01b2a4e4e) collection in the **Personal Workspace**. 2. Select the **Update product** request: [Update product](https://request/5083062-581dd298-29aa-4c7b-911e-cf41ed2ea539). 3. Ensure an environment is selected that defines `{{baseUrl}}` and `{{api_key}}`. 4. Verify the **Path variable** `code` (e.g., `CF`). 5. Adjust the JSON body if needed (e.g., change `name` or `basePrice`). 6. Click **Send** to execute the request. --- ## Working with Examples and Mock Servers ### Adding examples Examples in Postman are saved request–response pairs. They are used for documentation and to power mock servers. To add or edit an example: 1. Open the [Update product](https://request/5083062-581dd298-29aa-4c7b-911e-cf41ed2ea539) request. 2. Send the request with the desired input. 3. In the **Response** pane, click **Save response > Save as example**. 4. Give the example a meaningful name (e.g., `Product updated successfully`, `Invalid input`). 5. Adjust the example’s status code, headers, and body if needed, then **Save**. You can create multiple examples per request for different status codes and scenarios. ### Creating and using a mock server Mock servers return responses from saved examples instead of calling the real backend. 1. From the [Grocery Shop API](https://collection/5083062-5e6f8226-f7dc-405a-90fc-33c01b2a4e4e) collection, use **Mock collection** (or **Create mock server** from the sidebar/collection menu). 2. Select **Grocery Shop API** as the collection and optionally choose an environment. 3. Give the mock a name (e.g., `Grocery Shop API Mock`) and choose **public** or **private** access. 4. Create the mock; Postman will give you a **mock URL**. 5. Replace `{{baseUrl}}` with this mock URL in your environment (or in a dedicated environment) to have all requests, including **Update product**, hit the mock instead of the real API. When a request is sent to the mock URL, Postman matches the request to the saved examples on the corresponding request (method + path) and returns the appropriate example. --- ## Publishing Documentation and Run in Postman ### Publishing documentation 1. Open the [Grocery Shop API](https://collection/5083062-5e6f8226-f7dc-405a-90fc-33c01b2a4e4e) collection. 2. Click **View documentation** or use the collection menu and select **Publish Docs**. 3. Choose visibility (team/public) and configure any custom domain options available to your plan. 4. Publish to get a documentation URL, such as: - `https://documenter.getpostman.com/view/{collection-id}` This published documentation will include: - Request details for **Update product**. - Examples (e.g., 200 and 400 responses). - Any descriptions you add at the collection, folder, or request level. ### Run in Postman button You can embed a **Run in Postman** button in external docs or web pages so others can import the [Grocery Shop API](https://collection/5083062-5e6f8226-f7dc-405a-90fc-33c01b2a4e4e) collection with one click. Example HTML snippet: ``` html ``` Replace `:collection-id` with the public ID of the published **Grocery Shop API** collection from the documentation settings. When users click this button, the full collection (including the **Update product** request and its examples) is imported into their Postman workspace. --- ### Plan steps (what this collection documentation contains) - Overview of the **Grocery Shop API** and its purpose. - Instructions for configuring the `{{baseUrl}}` variable in an environment. - Bearer token authentication setup with example `Authorization` header. - Detailed documentation for the **Update product** endpoint (`PUT {{baseUrl}}/api/v1/products/:code`), including: - Description - Path variable details - Request headers - Request body schema and field descriptions - Example request - Example responses (200 and 400) referencing saved examples. - Step‑by‑step guide for calling the endpoint from Postman. - How to add examples to the request and how they are used. - How to create and configure a mock server for this collection. - How to publish documentation and embed a **Run in Postman** button.

request.description: Retrieves a list of all available products
Creates a new product with the provided details
Retrieves a product by its unique code
Updates an existing product with the provided details
Deletes a product by its unique code

Retrieves a packaging option by its ID

response.name: Packaging option or product not found

request.description: Deletes a packaging option by its ID
Retrieves all packaging options for a specific product
Creates a new order with optimal packaging to minimize number of packages. The system will calculate the best way to package products using available bundle options.
